content.webTitle: World Cup 2014: Greece’s show of unity becomes lost in translation

fields.headline: World Cup 2014: Greece’s show of unity becomes lost in translation
fields.bodyText: Giorgos Karagounis spoke powerfully on the unity that exists within Greece’s squad. Giorgos Samaras took up the Fulham midfielder’s mantle and flatly denied there was unrest in the camp. The show of harmony was going so well until the former Celtic striker defended the defensive style that won Greece the 2004 European Championships and outlined his manager’s vision to “just defend well and score one goal, that’s it.” Said manager, Fernando Santos, looked at Samaras, waved his finger and interjected: “That is not what I said. That is not what I said.” Something may have been lost in translation and Santos’s irritation was aimed more at a journalist who relayed Samaras’s comment than at the player himself. But having dismissed rumours of a split in the squad ever since the vice-captain Kostas Katsouranis and Giannis Maniatis almost came to blows in a Greek Cup semi-final last season, another denial – and the subject matter – was not what Santos needed before Saturday’s difficult opening game against Colombia. The Greece coach is clearly sensitive on the playing style that brought unprecedented success to the country under Otto Rehhagel but has won few neutral admirers given its continuation since 2004. “Defence is not the most important feature of Greece,” insisted Santos. “The most important feature is Greece and the team itself. If we only played defensively we would lose.” Later, Samaras elaborated: “We have our way of playing and we have not changed from the style that has borne fruit in recent years. As the coach said it very eloquently, football is simple; you just have to defend your goal and score one goal. That’s it. In that sense I fully agree. “We have our approach, our philosophy and our way of playing and hopefully we will be competitive throughout the World Cup.” That prompted the intervention from Santos, although should Colombia sense fracture in their opponents they should bear in mind the impassioned words of Karagounis, Greece’s most-capped player. “In recent months we have shown our big advantage is that we play as a team on the pitch and outside of it,” he said. “In good moments and not so good moments we are always together. We are a close group. The starting XI against Colombia and the bench are one team. We trust in each other, and that is why I trust Giorgos to score tomorrow!”
